comment.author: 8793648@N06
comment._content: A bridge, but not THE bridge :). Looks like a cantilever through truss, similar to Brisbane's Story Bridge en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Story_Bridge. Photo circa 1920, maybe?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Ha! I think it was at the corner of Miller and Blue Streets, at 3.00 pm on Saturday 28 July 1923. SMH same date p.14, "Turning the First Sod - Ceremony Today" - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16083692 .Read all about it !

comment.author: 55324084@N04
comment._content: Good piece of detective work! Maybe the Powerhouse has the model, or - ? A mystery to be solved.

comment.author: 79583367@N02
comment._content: As I understand it, JJC Bradfield had such strength of character that it was he who decided to use the arch design, despite all the approvals and documentation referring to the cantelever design.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The woman wearing the fur coat vaguely resembles R.T. Ball's 2nd wife (Lillie May Hume) who he married in 1926...seen here nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16763839 ...maybe she was hanging out with him in 1923...maybe she's someone else...doesn't look like Edith Bradfield www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4689902068/in/set... ...nor Lady Fuller nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn6251040
